## Executive Summary <!---What are the Three Things You Need to Know-->

QE is an unconventional monetary policy where the Monetary Policy authority (Central Bank) buys long-term financial assets in order to increase the money supply and lower long-term interest rates.   It is usually undertaken after exhausting the usual methods of stimulating economic growth, namely lowering short-term interest rates through purchases of short-term government securities.

-  This presentation will cover instances of QE around the world, and their effect on US markets.

## Why is this Important?/In What Situation Would This Be Used

Because of the free movement of capital across borders, QE in a particular region will affect other economies. For example, if the ECB conducts a substantial QE, this can effectively ease monetary conditions in the US.

## Past QE

QE has been conducted in the past, most notably in response to the US Great Depression in the 1930s.
